review_title: Lacking non-profit culture and you should NOT give notice of resignation. Trust me.
job_title: Project Manager in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: The work is fairly simple- as IPRO is just a company for healthcare plans.
cons:
I recently gave notice of my resignation from IPRO after finding a job that felt like a non-profit. I did not like the fact that working at IPRO was synonymous with working at any Long Island medical office. After submitting notice of my resignation, I immediately faced retaliation (not being able to use or be paid for unused vacation days, being asked to commute on all days I was previously scheduled to work from home, etc.). 

I chose to look for employment elsewhere due to the culture at IPRO. As a person of color, I was uncomfortable with there being Trump supporters in the office. I also just wanted to be in a non-profit environment where I could do meaningful work. I’m really happy to be done with all of it and regret accepting the offer a year ago. IPRO screwing me out of payment upon my departure has only validated my initial impression of the company.

review_title: A company with lots of potential

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Success, NY
pros:
Interesting and purposeful work, concern for employees, flexible schedule options, fun company events (softball games, Thanksgiving pies), good team work, nice, friendly people willing to help each other, really good benefits, a lot of integrity, honest commitment to please customers and (this attitude appears to pervade the company), wellness program, very inexpensive gym in building, wellness benefit with reimbursement for 50% of $ spent (capped), great shopping center across the street, more but that's all that comes to mind at the moment :) 

I have worked at IPRO for a while and I am pretty happy there. It's a good place to work, not perfect, but better than most places, I would bet. For a smaller sized company, they put a lot of effort into saying "Thanks" to staff -- holiday pies and gift cards, summer ice cream, annual softball game/picnic with family welcome. I mean how many places do those things? 

Anyone who is not happy there needs to open their eyes and take a good look at them self. In general, people are about as happy as they make up their minds to be.
cons:
Contract work makes for some insecurity. 
Constant construction in parking lot/ garage.

job_title: Data Analyst in Lake Success, NY
pros: Wow! The last post looks to be written by a IPRO Director.  Who are you kidding? Yes, a gym is available but it's so small that most of your after hours workout time is spent waiting for equipment. And the shopping across the street. What benefit is that? You have thirty minutes to walk out of the building, across a 4 lane street, through a parking lot, eat lunch, shop and be back promptly at your desk before people start talking about you being late... If you take advantage of this benefit-I'd stop before you get a reputation of being lazy. The pies and $25 holiday bonus are no great reward either.   Biggest benefit is the price of coffee in the break room.
cons: I've been employed here for 5 years. In that time my computer hasn't been updated at all. The fax is always broken, the printer is always jammed ect.... I've got enough stress in my life than to deal with that everyday.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Success, NY
pros: Great employees. The flex schedule, which went away for the most part in the summer of 2014 was a huge bonus. My job was mostly stress-free.
cons:
Contracts might not get renewed and you could lose your job. Raises were slashed to 1.5% maximum; raises based on your annual review. 45-50 points would be the 1.5% for an extraordinary employee. I think 40-44 was 1.25% and 30-39 was 1%. Why kill yourself for an extra 0.5% when just do your job and you'd get 1%?

Promotions were rare, too.

job_title: Project Manager in Albany, NY
pros: Decent benefits, opportunities to be involved with interesting work.
cons: Management is completely detached from the experience of "embedded" employees and offers little to no support unless they hear of a problem from DOH.  There is no interest in investing long term in employees because the contracts are short term.  Communication is terrible.  They have quarterly Town Hall meetings but they're boring and the information shared could be transmitted in a memo and save everyone a couple of hours.  Top management is making the big bucks including major bonuses, but raises are limited to 3% per year.  And five sick days is a joke.

review_title: A wonderful work environment and culture. Great people!
job_title: Intern in Lake Success, NY
pros: The projects at this company are intended to benefit the common good, which makes your work all the more fulfilling. This is also a company where you will be able to meet the CEO and other top management in just days of working there, all of whom are very friendly and respectful.
cons: The organization is rather small, so the team I was put in consisted of me and only one other person. It would have been helpful to make more employees working on the project, but this factor motivated us to be more creative.

job_title: Quality Assurance in Lake Success, NY
pros: You get a day off every week or two
cons: This work environment has been called "toxic" in other reviews.   I can only echo that.   Management couldn't care less about you.   One example says it all.   They laid off 25-28 front line workers, people in many different disciplines and at different levels.  This because of new federal contract requirements.   At this exact time, the entire group of Senior Management and their families went on an all expense paid "retreat" to Lake Tahoe, for a week.     The cost of that junket for a nonprofit is scandalous.    If they had gone to a local venue they could have used those monetary resources to have saved a few jobs here.    It is disgraceful.

job_title: Quality Specialist in Lake Success, NY
pros: The Compressed work day schedule and 4 day work week is possible, this is essentially government contract waste tine work, stare at your monitor and shuffle the mouse around a lot.   ...that's about it.
cons:
The type of employee they MUST hire at IPRO is of professional caliber, IE Nurses, medical professionals and people with advanced degrees.   The basic salary a nurse can command “Out there” is much higher than IPRO pays, and the minimum number of vacation weeks a nurse gets in the NSUH system for example is four right out of school, with a FULL HOUR for lunch every day, not a half hour as IPRO graciously gives us.    

In addition most medical professionals are given time off for Continuing Education with a stipend for that too, in order to keep current.  I am sure as a QIO we want our medical people to be up to date right why don’t we offer this benefit?

Add to this IPRO forces us to sit at a demeaning desk with a stall instead of an office, I mean we have PhD’s and Lawyers sitting in an open non private area…. this is idiotic but we do it because most of us realize the work is important.  Because of all this the least a professional should be able to expect is to be treated with the respect due a professional. 

The usual reply to suggestions from the unwashed masses to management ,if there even is one, will be “we cant do this at this time” as are many replies to valid suggestions.   It is sort of a running joke out here among the rank and file IPRO employee.     That’s fine, but then don’t complain or be concerned that we have a high turn over rate.   As professionals we have the flexibility to go where we want, and we will do so when our situation becomes overly troublesome.

They claim to have a benefit package that is: ”unheard of in the industry”.    I have no idea what industry they are speaking of.    In the healthcare industry I have always had a 403b with employer contributions and, employee directed funds, non contributory health insurance and many of the other benefits offered.   In addition I used to have, and lost coming to work at this dump, 15 paid holidays, 12 sick days, 4 weeks vacation, in addition to a week for Continuing professional education, flexible schedule and I made 15% more than I make now, at IPRO with an annual Cost of living increase separate from merit raises; that I didn’t have to be evaluated for.  In addition, and most importantly, I was treated like a professional.      As a matter of fact the ONLY thing IPRO offers is the compressed schedule, take that away and watch the mass exodus happen.  
A few years ago IPRO cut the number of sick days in half…..at the same time we don’t want to spread communicable diseases like the flu as our clients; the Department of Health and CDC advise,    Many of us work in and out of hospitals and clinics where the communicability of these infectious agents is greatly enhanced.    How do we morally justify this?    What is unheard of in the industry, the healthcare industry, is 5 and only 5 sick days a year.    This is insulting.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Success, NY
pros: Management cares about the employees. Even in this struggling economy-IPRO continues to provide generous support of programs such as their wellness program.
cons: The uncertainty of contract work is very stressful. There has been some changes in recent years reflecting the current state of our economy. For example a decrease in wage increases. Although this is a con-it is better than most organizations that have cut increases entirely.

job_title: Project Advisor in Albany, NY
pros: I liked most of the people that worked at IPRO on a personal level.
cons:
Very little work. When there was a problem between the client and myself, after numerous times going to my immediate supervisor about it, nothing was done. I was basically told that their loyalty is to the client, and not their employee. The office I worked at (OCFS) was definitely the worst place to be. The people were unprofessional, rude and demeaning. They talked down to everyone they dealt with, and when anyone stood up for themselves, their lives were made miserable. Honestly, this company has serious issues that they need to work on. Talking to their employees, offering support and making them feel as though their voice is heard is a place to start. 
There was no work there - I spent 8 weeks making copies and reserving meeting rooms, and little else. I was told there would be project work, and that the office was overwhelmed with work, and needed someone to help. After 8 weeks, I gave up. There was nothing there that would be worthy to put on my resume after the job was up. 
IPRO did nothing to help me during the issues I had, and refused to move me to any other open positions. They were completely inconsiderate in how they handled many situations, and I will not be adding them to my resume!! It is embarrassing to say I worked for them!
